snippet: The Pentagon will deploy more missile interceptors on the Pacific Coast to counter the growing reach of North Korea’s weapons, a decision accelerated by Pyongyang’s recent belligerence.
abstract: Pentagon will spend $1 billion to deploy additional ballistic missile interceptors along the Pacific Coast to counter growing reach of North Korea's weapons; decision was accelerated by North's recent belligerence and indication that leader Kim Jong-un is resisting China's efforts to restrain him.

byline.original: By THOM SHANKER, DAVID E. SANGER and MARTIN FACKLER
byline.contributor: Thom Shanker and David E. Sanger reported from Washington, and Martin Fackler from Seoul, South Korea. Choe Sang-hun contributed reporting from Seoul, and William J. Broad from New York.

lead_paragraph: The Pentagon will deploy more missile interceptors on the Pacific Coast to counter the growing reach of North Korea’s weapons, a decision accelerated by Pyongyang’s recent belligerence.

headline.main: U.S. Is Bolstering Missile Defense to Deter North Korea
headline.print_headline: U.S. IS EXPANDING MISSILE DEFENSES On Pacific Coast

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject
